content.text: Let me get comprehensive zsh documentation, focusing on configuration. I'll fetch from both the official Zsh manual and the practical "Mastering Zsh" guide:

input.topic: configuration startup files zshrc options parameters

content.text:
================
CODE SNIPPETS
================
TITLE: Zsh Initialisation Options
DESCRIPTION: Details Zsh options related to initialisation and environment variable handling. Includes ALL_EXPORT for automatic parameter export, GLOBAL_EXPORT for controlling export behavior with builtins, GLOBAL_RCS for disabling system startup files, and RCS for controlling the sourcing of user startup files.

SOURCE: https://zsh.sourceforge.io/Doc/Release/Options

LANGUAGE: APIDOC
CODE:
```
ALL_EXPORT (`-a`, ksh: `-a`)
    All parameters subsequently defined are automatically exported.

GLOBAL_EXPORT <Z>
    If this option is set, passing the `-x` flag to the builtins `declare`, `float`, `integer`, `readonly` and `typeset` (but not `local`) will also set the `-g` flag; hence parameters exported to the environment will not be made local to the enclosing function, unless they were already or the flag `+g` is given explicitly. If the option is unset, exported parameters will be made local in just the same way as any other parameter. This option is set by default for backward compatibility; it is not recommended that its behaviour be relied upon. Note that the builtin `export` always sets both the `-x` and `-g` flags, and hence its effect extends beyond the scope of the enclosing function; this is the most portable way to achieve this behaviour.

GLOBAL_RCS (`+d`) <D>
    If this option is unset, the startup files `/etc/zprofile`, `/etc/zshrc`, `/etc/zlogin` and `/etc/zlogout` will not be run. It can be disabled and re-enabled at any time, including inside local startup files (`.zshrc`, etc.).

RCS (`+f`) <D>
    After `/etc/zshenv` is sourced on startup, source the `.zshenv`, `/etc/zprofile`, `.zprofile`, `/etc/zshrc`, `.zshrc`, `/etc/zlogin`, `.zlogin`, and `.zlogout` files, as described in [Files](https://zsh.sourceforge.io/Doc/Release/Files.html#Files). If this option is unset, the `/etc/zshenv` file is still sourced, but any of the others will not be; it can be set at any time to prevent the remaining startup files after the currently executing one from being sourced.
```

--------------------------------

TITLE: Zsh Initialization and Startup Options
DESCRIPTION: This section covers Zsh options related to shell initialization and startup files. These options affect how the shell environment is configured when it starts.

SOURCE: https://zsh.sourceforge.io/Doc/Release/zsh_9

LANGUAGE: zsh
CODE:
```
GLOBALEXPORT
GLOBALRCS
GLOBAL_EXPORT
GLOBAL_RCS
```

--------------------------------

TITLE: Zsh Initialization and Configuration Options
DESCRIPTION: Options related to the initialization process and configuration of Zsh, including handling of RCS and parameter expansion in rc files.

SOURCE: https://zsh.sourceforge.io/Doc/Release/zsh_10

LANGUAGE: zsh
CODE:
```
NO_RCS
NO_RC_EXPAND_PARAM
```

--------------------------------

TITLE: Zsh Options: NO_GLOBAL_RCS
DESCRIPTION: The NO_GLOBAL_RCS option controls the loading of global startup files. When set, Zsh will not load system-wide initialization files like /etc/zshrc, allowing for more localized configurations.

SOURCE: https://zsh.sourceforge.io/Doc/Release/zsh_10

LANGUAGE: zsh
CODE:
```
# Example usage:
set +o global_rcs  # Equivalent to set -o noglobal_rcs
```

--------------------------------

TITLE: Zsh ZDOTDIR Configuration
DESCRIPTION: Specifies the directory where zsh looks for its startup files (e.g., .zshrc), overriding the default behavior of using the user's home directory.

SOURCE: https://zsh.sourceforge.io/Doc/Release/Parameters

LANGUAGE: zsh
CODE:
```
ZDOTDIR
    
The directory to search for shell startup files (.zshrc, etc), if not `$HOME`.
```

--------------------------------

TITLE: zcalc Initialization and Configuration
DESCRIPTION: zcalc can be configured using the ~/.zcalcrc file, which is sourced upon startup. This allows for setting shell options and customizing the calculator's behavior. The zsh/mathfunc module can also be loaded for additional mathematical functions.

SOURCE: https://zsh.sourceforge.io/Doc/Release/User-Contributions

LANGUAGE: zsh
CODE:
```
# ~/.zcalcrc example:
emulate -L zsh
setopt extendedglob

# Loading zsh/mathfunc module (if available):
zsh/mathfunc
```

--------------------------------

TITLE: zsh-newuser-install Function
DESCRIPTION: The zsh-newuser-install function from the zsh/newuser module aids in configuring shell options for new users. It presents interactive menus to customize initialization scripts like ~/.zshrc. The -f option forces execution even if startup files exist, and changes are restricted to marked sections, with backups saved as .zni files.

SOURCE: https://zsh.sourceforge.io/Doc/Release/User-Contributions

LANGUAGE: zsh
CODE:
```
zsh-newuser-install [ -f ]
```

--------------------------------

TITLE: Zsh Options: Initialization and Scripts
DESCRIPTION: Discusses Zsh options related to initialization and script execution. This includes inhibiting global startup files and sourcing startup files, as well as options affecting script and function behavior.

SOURCE: https://zsh.sourceforge.io/Doc/Release/zsh_4

LANGUAGE: zsh
CODE:
```
# Global startup files, inhibiting
# Refer to: https://zsh.sourceforge.io/Doc/Release/Options.html#index-startup-files_002c-global_002c-inhibiting

# Startup files, sourcing
# Refer to: https://zsh.sourceforge.io/Doc/Release/Options.html#index-startup-files_002c-sourcing

# Status, on exit from pipeline
# Refer to: https://zsh.sourceforge.io/Doc/Release/Options.html#index-status_002c-on-exit-from-pipeline
```

--------------------------------

TITLE: Zsh Configuration Files
DESCRIPTION: Lists common Zsh configuration files and their default locations. These files are read by Zsh at different stages of its startup process to customize the shell environment. They can be pre-compiled using the `zcompile` command for faster loading.

SOURCE: https://zsh.sourceforge.io/Doc/Release/Files

LANGUAGE: zsh
CODE:
```
$ZDOTDIR/.zshenv
$ZDOTDIR/.zprofile
$ZDOTDIR/.zshrc
$ZDOTDIR/.zlogin
$ZDOTDIR/.zlogout
${TMPPREFIX}* (default is /tmp/zsh*)
/etc/zshenv
/etc/zprofile
/etc/zshrc
/etc/zlogin
/etc/zlogout (installation-specific - /etc is the default)
```

--------------------------------

TITLE: Zsh RCS and GLOBAL_RCS Options
DESCRIPTION: Explains how the RCS and GLOBAL_RCS options control the reading of startup files and the saving of history. If RCS is unset, history files are not saved upon exit.

SOURCE: https://zsh.sourceforge.io/Doc/Release/Files

LANGUAGE: zsh
CODE:
```
# RCS option affects all startup files and history saving.
# GLOBAL_RCS option affects only global startup files (paths starting with '/').

# Example of conditional execution based on RCS option:
if [[ -o rcs ]]; then
  # Code to be executed only when RCS is enabled
  # This is useful for code that should not run with 'zsh -f'
  echo "RCS option is enabled."
fi

# If RCS is unset when the shell exits, no history file will be saved.
```

--------------------------------

TITLE: Zsh Startup/Shutdown Files
DESCRIPTION: This entry pertains to the use of the 'LOGIN' mechanism within Zsh's startup and shutdown files, influencing how the shell initializes and terminates.

SOURCE: https://zsh.sourceforge.io/Doc/Release/zsh_10

LANGUAGE: zsh
CODE:
```
LOGIN, use of
```

--------------------------------

TITLE: Zsh Startup and Shutdown Files
DESCRIPTION: Details the purpose and usage of Zsh's startup and shutdown files, including zlogin, zprofile, zshenv, and zshrc. These files control shell initialization and session management.

SOURCE: https://zsh.sourceforge.io/Doc/Release/zsh_5

LANGUAGE: zsh
CODE:
```
# zlogin: Executed when a login shell is started.
# zprofile: Executed for login shells, after zshenv.
# zshenv: Executed for all shells, before other startup files.
# zshrc: Executed for interactive shells, after zshenv and zprofile (if applicable).
```

--------------------------------

TITLE: Compinit Options for Dumped Configuration
DESCRIPTION: Controls how `compinit` handles dumped configuration files for faster initialization. Use `-D` to disable dumping, `-d <dumpfile>` to specify a custom dump file name, and `-C` to skip the check for new functions (only creates a dump if none exists).

SOURCE: https://zsh.sourceforge.io/Doc/Release/Completion-System

LANGUAGE: zsh
CODE:
```
# Disable dumping of configuration
compinit -D

# Specify a custom dump file
compinit -d ~/.zcompdump_custom

# Skip check for new functions and create dump only if it doesn't exist
compinit -C
```

--------------------------------

TITLE: Enabling the run-help Function in Zsh
DESCRIPTION: This snippet illustrates how to configure your `.zshrc` or equivalent startup file to use the autoloadable `run-help` function. It involves unaliasing the default `run-help` and then autoloading the function.

SOURCE: https://zsh.sourceforge.io/Doc/Release/User-Contributions

LANGUAGE: zsh
CODE:
```
unalias run-help
autoload run-help
```

--------------------------------

TITLE: Configuring HELPDIR for Custom Help Files
DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows how to set the `HELPDIR` environment variable in a Zsh startup file. This variable tells the `run-help` function where to locate custom help files.

SOURCE: https://zsh.sourceforge.io/Doc/Release/User-Contributions

LANGUAGE: zsh
CODE:
```
HELPDIR=~/zsh_help
```

--------------------------------

TITLE: Zsh Startup File Execution Order
DESCRIPTION: Describes the order in which Zsh reads configuration files for different shell types (login, interactive) and the role of environment variables like ZDOTDIR and system-wide files.

SOURCE: https://zsh.sourceforge.io/Doc/Release/Files

LANGUAGE: zsh
CODE:
```
# System-wide environment variables (always read)
/etc/zshenv

# User-specific environment variables
$ZDOTDIR/.zshenv

# Login shell specific files
# System-wide profile
/etc/zprofile
# User-specific profile
```

TITLE: Zsh Configuration Variables
DESCRIPTION: Documentation for key Zsh configuration variables affecting shell behavior.

SOURCE: https://zsh.sourceforge.io/Doc/Release/Parameters

LANGUAGE: APIDOC
CODE:
```
HISTSIZE <S>
    The maximum number of events stored in the internal history list. If you use the `HIST_EXPIRE_DUPS_FIRST` option, setting this value larger than the `SAVEHIST` size will give you the difference as a cushion for saving duplicated history events. If this is made local, it is not implicitly set to 0, but may be explicitly set locally.

HOME <S>
    The default argument for the `cd` command. This is not set automatically by the shell in `sh`, `ksh` or `csh` emulation, but it is typically present in the environment anyway, and if it becomes set it has its usual special behaviour.

IFS <S>
    Internal field separators (by default space, tab, newline and NUL), that are used to separate words which result from command or parameter expansion and words read by the `read` builtin. Any characters from the set space, tab and newline that appear in the IFS are called _IFS white space_. One or more IFS white space characters or one non-IFS white space character together with any adjacent IFS white space character delimit a field. If an IFS white space character appears twice consecutively in the IFS, this character is treated as if it were not an IFS white space character. If the parameter is unset, the default is used. Note this has a different effect from setting the parameter to an empty string.

KEYBOARD_HACK
    This variable defines a character to be removed from the end of the command line before interpreting it (interactive shells only). It is intended to fix the problem with keys placed annoyingly close to return and replaces the `SUNKEYBOARDHACK` option which did this for backquotes only. Should the chosen character be one of singlequote, doublequote or backquote, there must also be an odd number of them on the command line for the last one to be removed. For backward compatibility, if the `SUNKEYBOARDHACK` option is explicitly set, the value of `KEYBOARD_HACK` reverts to backquote. If the option is explicitly unset, this variable is set to empty.

KEYTIMEOUT
    The time the shell waits, in hundredths of seconds, for another key to be pressed when reading bound multi-character sequences.

LANG <S>
    This variable determines the locale category for any category not specifically selected via a variable starting with ‚Äò`LC_`‚Äô.

LC_ALL <S>
    This variable overrides the value of the ‚Äò`LANG`‚Äô variable and the value of any of the other variables starting with ‚Äò`LC_`‚Äô.

LC_COLLATE <S>
    This variable determines the locale category for character collation information within ranges in glob brackets and for sorting.

LC_CTYPE <S>
    This variable determines the locale category for character handling functions. If the `MULTIBYTE` option is in effect this variable or `LANG` should contain a value that reflects the character set in use, even if it is a single-byte character set, unless only the 7-bit subset (ASCII) is used. For example, if the character set is ISO-8859-1, a suitable value might be `en_US.iso88591` (certain Linux distributions) or `en_US.ISO8859-1` (MacOS).

LC_MESSAGES <S>
    This variable determines the language in which messages should be written. Note that zsh does not use message catalogs.

LC_NUMERIC <S>
    This variable affects the decimal point character and thousands separator character for the formatted input/output functions and string conversion functions. Note that zsh ignores this setting when parsing floating point mathematical expressions.

LC_TIME <S>
    This variable determines the locale category for date and time formatting in prompt escape sequences.

LINES <S>
    The number of lines for this terminal session. Used for printing select lists and for the line editor.

LISTMAX
    In the line editor, the number of matches to list without asking first. If the value is negative, the list will be shown if it spans at most as many lines as given by the absolute value. If set to zero, the shell asks only if the top of the listing would scroll off the screen.

MAIL
```

TITLE: Zsh Configuration Parameters
DESCRIPTION: This section details various configuration parameters for the Zsh shell, covering aspects like mail checking, path management, prompt customization, and command execution behavior. These parameters allow users to customize the shell's functionality and appearance.

SOURCE: https://zsh.sourceforge.io/Doc/Release/Parameters

LANGUAGE: APIDOC
CODE:
```
MAILCHECK:
    The interval in seconds between checks for new mail.

mailpath <S> <Z> (MAILPATH <S>):
    An array (colon-separated list) of filenames to check for new mail. Each filename can be followed by a ‚Äò?‚Äò and a message that will be printed. The message will undergo parameter expansion, command substitution and arithmetic expansion with the variable $_ defined as the name of the file that has changed. The default message is ‚ÄòYou have new mail‚Äò. If an element is a directory instead of a file the shell will recursively check every file in every subdirectory of the element.

manpath <S> <Z> (MANPATH <S> <Z>):
    An array (colon-separated list) whose value is not used by the shell. The manpath array can be useful, however, since setting it also sets MANPATH, and vice versa.

match:
    Arrays set by the shell when the b globbing flag is used in pattern matches.

mbegin:
    Arrays set by the shell when the b globbing flag is used in pattern matches.

mend:
    Arrays set by the shell when the b globbing flag is used in pattern matches.

MATCH:
    Set by the shell when the m globbing flag is used in pattern matches.

MBEGIN:
    Set by the shell when the m globbing flag is used in pattern matches.

MEND:
    Set by the shell when the m globbing flag is used in pattern matches.

module_path <S> <Z> (MODULE_PATH <S>):
    An array (colon-separated list) of directories that zmodload searches for dynamically loadable modules. This is initialized to a standard pathname, usually ‚Äò/usr/local/lib/zsh/$ZSH_VERSION‚Äò. (The ‚Äò/usr/local/lib‚Äò part varies from installation to installation.) For security reasons, any value set in the environment when the shell is started will be ignored. These parameters only exist if the installation supports dynamic module loading.

NULLCMD <S>:
    The command name to assume if a redirection is specified with no command. Defaults to cat. For sh/ksh behavior, change this to :. For csh-like behavior, unset this parameter; the shell will print an error message if null commands are entered.

path <S> <Z> (PATH <S>):
    An array (colon-separated list) of directories to search for commands. When this parameter is set, each directory is scanned and all files found are put in a hash table.

POSTEDIT <S>:
    This string is output whenever the line editor exits. It usually contains termcap strings to reset the terminal.

PROMPT <S> <Z>:
    Same as PS1.

PROMPT2 <S> <Z>:
    Same as PS2.

PROMPT3 <S> <Z>:
    Same as PS3.

PROMPT4 <S> <Z>:
    Same as PS4.

prompt <S> <Z>:
    Same as PS1.

PROMPT_EOL_MARK:
    When the PROMPT_CR and PROMPT_SP options are set, the PROMPT_EOL_MARK parameter can be used to customize how the end of partial lines are shown. This parameter undergoes prompt expansion, with the PROMPT_PERCENT option set. If not set, the default behavior is equivalent to the value ‚Äò%B%S%#%s%b‚Äò.

PS1 <S>:
    The primary prompt string, printed before a command is read. It undergoes a special form of expansion before being displayed; see Prompt Expansion. The default is ‚Äò%m%# ‚Äò.

PS2 <S>:
    The secondary prompt, printed when the shell needs more information to complete a command. It is expanded in the same way as PS1. The default is ‚Äò%_> ‚Äò, which displays any shell constructs or quotation marks which are currently being processed.

PS3 <S>:
    Selection prompt used within a select loop. It is expanded in the same way as PS1. The default is ‚Äò?# ‚Äò.

PS4 <S>:
    The execution trace prompt. Default is ‚Äò+%N:%i> ‚Äò, which displays the name of the current shell structure and the line number within it. In sh or ksh emulation, the default is ‚Äò+ ‚Äò.

psvar <S> <Z> (PSVAR <S>):
    An array (colon-separated list) whose elements can be used in PROMPT strings. Setting psvar also sets PSVAR, and vice versa.

READNULLCMD <S>:
    The command name to assume if a single input redirection is specified with no command. Defaults to more.

REPORTMEMORY:
    If nonnegative, commands whose maximum resident set size (roughly speaking, main memory usage) in kilobytes is greater than this value have timing statistics reported. The format used to output statistics is the value of the TIMEFMT parameter, which is the same as for the REPORTTIME variable and the time builtin; note that by default this does not output memory usage. Appending " max RSS %M" to the value of TIMEFMT causes it to output the value that triggered the report. If REPORTTIME is also in use, at most a single report is printed for both triggers. This feature requires the getrusage() system call, commonly supported by modern Unix-like systems.

REPORTTIME:
    
```

TITLE: Zsh Completion Options
DESCRIPTION: Configuration options for Zsh's command-line completion system. These options control how completions are listed, selected, and displayed, affecting user experience and efficiency.

SOURCE: https://zsh.sourceforge.io/Doc/Release/Options

LANGUAGE: APIDOC
CODE:
```
ALWAYS_LAST_PROMPT
    If unset, key functions that list completions try to return to the last prompt if given a numeric argument. If set these functions try to return to the last prompt if given _no_ numeric argument.

ALWAYS_TO_END
    If a completion is performed with the cursor within a word, and a full completion is inserted, the cursor is moved to the end of the word. That is, the cursor is moved to the end of the word if either a single match is inserted or menu completion is performed.

AUTO_LIST (-9)
    Automatically list choices on an ambiguous completion.

AUTO_MENU
    Automatically use menu completion after the second consecutive request for completion, for example by pressing the tab key repeatedly. This option is overridden by `MENU_COMPLETE`.

AUTO_NAME_DIRS
    Any parameter that is set to the absolute name of a directory immediately becomes a name for that directory, that will be used by the ‚Äò`%~`‚Äô and related prompt sequences, and will be available when completion is performed on a word starting with ‚Äò`~`‚Äô. (Otherwise, the parameter must be used in the form ‚Äò`~`param‚Äô first.)

AUTO_PARAM_KEYS
    If a parameter name was completed and a following character (normally a space) automatically inserted, and the next character typed is one of those that have to come directly after the name (like ‚Äò`}`‚Äô, ‚Äò`:`‚Äô, etc.), the automatically added character is deleted, so that the character typed comes immediately after the parameter name. Completion in a brace expansion is affected similarly: the added character is a ‚Äò`,`‚Äô, which will be removed if ‚Äò`}`‚Äô is typed next.

AUTO_PARAM_SLASH
    If a parameter is completed whose content is the name of a directory, then add a trailing slash instead of a space.

AUTO_REMOVE_SLASH
    When the last character resulting from a completion is a slash and the next character typed is a word delimiter, a slash, or a character that ends a command (such as a semicolon or an ampersand), remove the slash.

BASH_AUTO_LIST
    On an ambiguous completion, automatically list choices when the completion function is called twice in succession. This takes precedence over `AUTO_LIST`. The setting of `LIST_AMBIGUOUS` is respected. If `AUTO_MENU` is set, the menu behaviour will then start with the third press. Note that this will not work with `MENU_COMPLETE`, since repeated completion calls immediately cycle through the list in that case.

COMPLETE_ALIASES
    Prevents aliases on the command line from being internally substituted before completion is attempted. The effect is to make the alias a distinct command for completion purposes.

COMPLETE_IN_WORD
    If unset, the cursor is set to the end of the word if completion is started. Otherwise it stays there and completion is done from both ends.

GLOB_COMPLETE
    When the current word has a glob pattern, do not insert all the words resulting from the expansion but generate matches as for completion and cycle through them like `MENU_COMPLETE`. The matches are generated as if a ‚Äò`*`‚Äô was added to the end of the word, or inserted at the cursor when `COMPLETE_IN_WORD` is set. This actually uses pattern matching, not globbing, so it works not only for files but for any completion, such as options, user names, etc. Note that when the pattern matcher is used, matching control (for example, case-insensitive or anchored matching) cannot be used. This limitation only applies when the current word contains a pattern; simply turning on the `GLOB_COMPLETE` option does not have this effect.

HASH_LIST_ALL
    Whenever a command completion or spelling correction is attempted, make sure the entire command path is hashed first. This makes the first completion slower but avoids false reports of spelling errors.

LIST_AMBIGUOUS
    This option works when `AUTO_LIST` or `BASH_AUTO_LIST` is also set. If there is an unambiguous prefix to insert on the command line, that is done without a completion list being displayed; in other words, auto-listing behaviour only takes place when nothing would be inserted. In the case of `BASH_AUTO_LIST`, this means that the list will be delayed to the third call of the function.

LIST_BEEP
    Beep on an ambiguous completion. More accurately, this forces the completion widgets to return status 1 on an ambiguous completion, which causes the shell to beep if the option `BEEP` is also set; this may be modified if completion is called from a user-defined widget.

LIST_PACKED
    Try to make the completion list smaller (occupying less lines) by printing the matches in columns with different widths.

LIST_ROWS_FIRST
    Lay out the matches in completion lists sorted horizontally, that is, the second match is to the right of the first one, not under it as usual.

LIST_TYPES (-X)
    
```

```
    All parameters subsequently defined are automatically exported.

GLOBAL_EXPORT <Z>
    If this option is set, passing the `-x` flag to the builtins `declare`, `float`, `integer`, `readonly` and `typeset` (but not `local`) will also set the `-g` flag; hence parameters exported to the environment will not be made local to the enclosing function, unless they were already or the flag `+g` is given explicitly. If the option is unset, exported parameters will be made local in just the same way as any other parameter. This option is set by default for backward compatibility; it is not recommended that its behaviour be relied upon. Note that the builtin `export` always sets both the `-x` and `-g` flags, and hence its effect extends beyond the scope of the enclosing function; this is the most portable way to achieve this behaviour.

GLOBAL_RCS (`+d`) <D>
    If this option is unset, the startup files `/etc/zprofile`, `/etc/zshrc`, `/etc/zlogin` and `/etc/zlogout` will not be run. It can be disabled and re-enabled at any time, including inside local startup files (`.zshrc`, etc.).

RCS (`+f`) <D>
    After `/etc/zshenv` is sourced on startup, source the `.zshenv`, `/etc/zprofile`, `.zprofile`, `/etc/zshrc`, `.zshrc`, `/etc/zlogin`, `.zlogin`, and `.zlogout` files, as described in [Files](https://zsh.sourceforge.io/Doc/Release/Files.html#Files). If this option is unset, the `/etc/zshenv` file is still sourced, but any of the others will not be; it can be set at any time to prevent the remaining startup files after the currently executing one from being sourced.
```

TITLE: Zsh Configuration Variables
DESCRIPTION: Documentation for key Zsh configuration variables affecting shell behavior.

SOURCE: https://zsh.sourceforge.io/Doc/Release/Parameters

LANGUAGE: APIDOC
CODE:
```
HISTSIZE <S>
    The maximum number of events stored in the internal history list. If you use the `HIST_EXPIRE_DUPS_FIRST` option, setting this value larger than the `SAVEHIST` size will give you the difference as a cushion for saving duplicated history events. If this is made local, it is not implicitly set to 0, but may be explicitly set locally.

HOME <S>
    The default argument for the `cd` command. This is not set automatically by the shell in `sh`, `ksh` or `csh` emulation, but it is typically present in the environment anyway, and if it becomes set it has its usual special behaviour.

IFS <S>
    Internal field separators (by default space, tab, newline and NUL), that are used to separate words which result from command or parameter expansion and words read by the `read` builtin. Any characters from the set space, tab and newline that appear in the IFS are called _IFS white space_. One or more IFS white space characters or one non-IFS white space character together with any adjacent IFS white space character delimit a field. If an IFS white space character appears twice consecutively in the IFS, this character is treated as if it were not an IFS white space character. If the parameter is unset, the default is used. Note this has a different effect from setting the parameter to an empty string.

KEYBOARD_HACK
    This variable defines a character to be removed from the end of the command line before interpreting it (interactive shells only). It is intended to fix the problem with keys placed annoyingly close to return and replaces the `SUNKEYBOARDHACK` option which did this for backquotes only. Should the chosen character be one of singlequote, doublequote or backquote, there must also be an odd number of them on the command line for the last one to be removed. For backward compatibility, if the `SUNKEYBOARDHACK` option is explicitly set, the value of `KEYBOARD_HACK` reverts to backquote. If the option is explicitly unset, this variable is set to empty.

KEYTIMEOUT
    The time the shell waits, in hundredths of seconds, for another key to be pressed when reading bound multi-character sequences.

LANG <S>
    This variable determines the locale category for any category not specifically selected via a variable starting with ‚Äò`LC_`‚Äô.

LC_ALL <S>
    This variable overrides the value of the ‚Äò`LANG`‚Äô variable and the value of any of the other variables starting with ‚Äò`LC_`‚Äô.

LC_COLLATE <S>
    This variable determines the locale category for character collation information within ranges in glob brackets and for sorting.

LC_CTYPE <S>
    This variable determines the locale category for character handling functions. If the `MULTIBYTE` option is in effect this variable or `LANG` should contain a value that reflects the character set in use, even if it is a single-byte character set, unless only the 7-bit subset (ASCII) is used. For example, if the character set is ISO-8859-1, a suitable value might be `en_US.iso88591` (certain Linux distributions) or `en_US.ISO8859-1` (MacOS).

LC_MESSAGES <S>
    This variable determines the language in which messages should be written. Note that zsh does not use message catalogs.

LC_NUMERIC <S>
    This variable affects the decimal point character and thousands separator character for the formatted input/output functions and string conversion functions. Note that zsh ignores this setting when parsing floating point mathematical expressions.

LC_TIME <S>
    This variable determines the locale category for date and time formatting in prompt escape sequences.

LINES <S>
    The number of lines for this terminal session. Used for printing select lists and for the line editor.

LISTMAX
    In the line editor, the number of matches to list without asking first. If the value is negative, the list will be shown if it spans at most as many lines as given by the absolute value. If set to zero, the shell asks only if the top of the listing would scroll off the screen.

MAIL
    
```

TITLE: Startup Scripts in Compatibility Modes
DESCRIPTION: Describes the startup script execution flow when Zsh is invoked in sh or ksh compatibility modes. It specifies which profile scripts are sourced and how the ENV environment variable is handled.

SOURCE: https://zsh.sourceforge.io/Doc/Release/Invocation

LANGUAGE: zsh
CODE:
```
The usual zsh startup/shutdown scripts are not executed. Login shells source `/etc/profile` followed by `$HOME/.profile`. If the `ENV` environment variable is set on invocation, `$ENV` is sourced after the profile scripts. The value of `ENV` is subjected to parameter expansion, command substitution, and arithmetic expansion before being interpreted as a pathname. Note that the `PRIVILEGED` option also affects the execution of startup files.
```

TITLE: Zsh Configuration Parameters
DESCRIPTION: This section details various configuration parameters for the Zsh shell, covering aspects like mail checking, path management, prompt customization, and command execution behavior. These parameters allow users to customize the shell's functionality and appearance.

SOURCE: https://zsh.sourceforge.io/Doc/Release/Parameters

LANGUAGE: APIDOC
CODE:
```
MAILCHECK:
    The interval in seconds between checks for new mail.

mailpath <S> <Z> (MAILPATH <S>):
    An array (colon-separated list) of filenames to check for new mail. Each filename can be followed by a ‚Äò?‚Äò and a message that will be printed. The message will undergo parameter expansion, command substitution and arithmetic expansion with the variable $_ defined as the name of the file that has changed. The default message is ‚ÄòYou have new mail‚Äò. If an element is a directory instead of a file the shell will recursively check every file in every subdirectory of the element.

manpath <S> <Z> (MANPATH <S> <Z>):
    An array (colon-separated list) whose value is not used by the shell. The manpath array can be useful, however, since setting it also sets MANPATH, and vice versa.

match:
    Arrays set by the shell when the b globbing flag is used in pattern matches.

mbegin:
    Arrays set by the shell when the b globbing flag is used in pattern matches.

mend:
    Arrays set by the shell when the b globbing flag is used in pattern matches.

MATCH:
    Set by the shell when the m globbing flag is used in pattern matches.

MBEGIN:
    Set by the shell when the m globbing flag is used in pattern matches.

MEND:
    Set by the shell when the m globbing flag is used in pattern matches.

module_path <S> <Z> (MODULE_PATH <S>):
    An array (colon-separated list) of directories that zmodload searches for dynamically loadable modules. This is initialized to a standard pathname, usually ‚Äò/usr/local/lib/zsh/$ZSH_VERSION‚Äò. (The ‚Äò/usr/local/lib‚Äò part varies from installation to installation.) For security reasons, any value set in the environment when the shell is started will be ignored. These parameters only exist if the installation supports dynamic module loading.

NULLCMD <S>:
    The command name to assume if a redirection is specified with no command. Defaults to cat. For sh/ksh behavior, change this to :. For csh-like behavior, unset this parameter; the shell will print an error message if null commands are entered.

path <S> <Z> (PATH <S>):
    An array (colon-separated list) of directories to search for commands. When this parameter is set, each directory is scanned and all files found are put in a hash table.

POSTEDIT <S>:
    This string is output whenever the line editor exits. It usually contains termcap strings to reset the terminal.

PROMPT <S> <Z>:
    Same as PS1.

PROMPT2 <S> <Z>:
    Same as PS2.

PROMPT3 <S> <Z>:
    Same as PS3.

PROMPT4 <S> <Z>:
    Same as PS4.

prompt <S> <Z>:
    Same as PS1.

PROMPT_EOL_MARK:
    When the PROMPT_CR and PROMPT_SP options are set, the PROMPT_EOL_MARK parameter can be used to customize how the end of partial lines are shown. This parameter undergoes prompt expansion, with the PROMPT_PERCENT option set. If not set, the default behavior is equivalent to the value ‚Äò%B%S%#%s%b‚Äò.

PS1 <S>:
    The primary prompt string, printed before a command is read. It undergoes a special form of expansion before being displayed; see Prompt Expansion. The default is ‚Äò%m%# ‚Äò.

PS2 <S>:
    The secondary prompt, printed when the shell needs more information to complete a command. It is expanded in the same way as PS1. The default is ‚Äò%_> ‚Äò, which displays any shell constructs or quotation marks which are currently being processed.

PS3 <S>:
    Selection prompt used within a select loop. It is expanded in the same way as PS1. The default is ‚Äò?# ‚Äò.

PS4 <S>:
    The execution trace prompt. Default is ‚Äò+%N:%i> ‚Äò, which displays the name of the current shell structure and the line number within it. In sh or ksh emulation, the default is ‚Äò+ ‚Äò.

psvar <S> <Z> (PSVAR <S>):
    An array (colon-separated list) whose elements can be used in PROMPT strings. Setting psvar also sets PSVAR, and vice versa.

READNULLCMD <S>:
    The command name to assume if a single input redirection is specified with no command. Defaults to more.

REPORTMEMORY:
    If nonnegative, commands whose maximum resident set size (roughly speaking, main memory usage) in kilobytes is greater than this value have timing statistics reported. The format used to output statistics is the value of the TIMEFMT parameter, which is the same as for the REPORTTIME variable and the time builtin; note that by default this does not output memory usage. Appending " max RSS %M" to the value of TIMEFMT causes it to output the value that triggered the report. If REPORTTIME is also in use, at most a single report is printed for both triggers. This feature requires the getrusage() system call, commonly supported by modern Unix-like systems.

REPORTTIME:
    
```

--------------------------------

TITLE: Zsh Expansion and Globbing Options
DESCRIPTION: Options that control how parameters are expanded and how filename globbing is performed.

SOURCE: https://zsh.sourceforge.io/Doc/Release/zsh_10

LANGUAGE: zsh
CODE:
```
# NORCEXPANDPARAM: Do not expand parameters in rc files
# NOREMATCHPCRE: Do not use PCRE for matching
# NOSHGLOB: Do not use sh-compatible globbing
```

--------------------------------

TITLE: Zsh Completion Options
DESCRIPTION: Configuration options for Zsh's command-line completion system. These options control how completions are listed, selected, and displayed, affecting user experience and efficiency.

SOURCE: https://zsh.sourceforge.io/Doc/Release/Options

LANGUAGE: APIDOC
CODE:
```
ALWAYS_LAST_PROMPT
    If unset, key functions that list completions try to return to the last prompt if given a numeric argument. If set these functions try to return to the last prompt if given _no_ numeric argument.

ALWAYS_TO_END
    If a completion is performed with the cursor within a word, and a full completion is inserted, the cursor is moved to the end of the word. That is, the cursor is moved to the end of the word if either a single match is inserted or menu completion is performed.

AUTO_LIST (-9)
    Automatically list choices on an ambiguous completion.

AUTO_MENU
    Automatically use menu completion after the second consecutive request for completion, for example by pressing the tab key repeatedly. This option is overridden by `MENU_COMPLETE`.

AUTO_NAME_DIRS
    Any parameter that is set to the absolute name of a directory immediately becomes a name for that directory, that will be used by the ‚Äò`%~`‚Äô and related prompt sequences, and will be available when completion is performed on a word starting with ‚Äò`~`‚Äô. (Otherwise, the parameter must be used in the form ‚Äò`~`param‚Äô first.)

AUTO_PARAM_KEYS
    If a parameter name was completed and a following character (normally a space) automatically inserted, and the next character typed is one of those that have to come directly after the name (like ‚Äò`}`‚Äô, ‚Äò`:`‚Äô, etc.), the automatically added character is deleted, so that the character typed comes immediately after the parameter name. Completion in a brace expansion is affected similarly: the added character is a ‚Äò`,`‚Äô, which will be removed if ‚Äò`}`‚Äô is typed next.

AUTO_PARAM_SLASH
    If a parameter is completed whose content is the name of a directory, then add a trailing slash instead of a space.

AUTO_REMOVE_SLASH
    When the last character resulting from a completion is a slash and the next character typed is a word delimiter, a slash, or a character that ends a command (such as a semicolon or an ampersand), remove the slash.

BASH_AUTO_LIST
    On an ambiguous completion, automatically list choices when the completion function is called twice in succession. This takes precedence over `AUTO_LIST`. The setting of `LIST_AMBIGUOUS` is respected. If `AUTO_MENU` is set, the menu behaviour will then start with the third press. Note that this will not work with `MENU_COMPLETE`, since repeated completion calls immediately cycle through the list in that case.

COMPLETE_ALIASES
    Prevents aliases on the command line from being internally substituted before completion is attempted. The effect is to make the alias a distinct command for completion purposes.

COMPLETE_IN_WORD
    If unset, the cursor is set to the end of the word if completion is started. Otherwise it stays there and completion is done from both ends.

GLOB_COMPLETE
    When the current word has a glob pattern, do not insert all the words resulting from the expansion but generate matches as for completion and cycle through them like `MENU_COMPLETE`. The matches are generated as if a ‚Äò`*`‚Äô was added to the end of the word, or inserted at the cursor when `COMPLETE_IN_WORD` is set. This actually uses pattern matching, not globbing, so it works not only for files but for any completion, such as options, user names, etc. Note that when the pattern matcher is used, matching control (for example, case-insensitive or anchored matching) cannot be used. This limitation only applies when the current word contains a pattern; simply turning on the `GLOB_COMPLETE` option does not have this effect.

HASH_LIST_ALL
    Whenever a command completion or spelling correction is attempted, make sure the entire command path is hashed first. This makes the first completion slower but avoids false reports of spelling errors.

LIST_AMBIGUOUS
    This option works when `AUTO_LIST` or `BASH_AUTO_LIST` is also set. If there is an unambiguous prefix to insert on the command line, that is done without a completion list being displayed; in other words, auto-listing behaviour only takes place when nothing would be inserted. In the case of `BASH_AUTO_LIST`, this means that the list will be delayed to the third call of the function.

LIST_BEEP
    Beep on an ambiguous completion. More accurately, this forces the completion widgets to return status 1 on an ambiguous completion, which causes the shell to beep if the option `BEEP` is also set; this may be modified if completion is called from a user-defined widget.

LIST_PACKED
    Try to make the completion list smaller (occupying less lines) by printing the matches in columns with different widths.

LIST_ROWS_FIRST
    Lay out the matches in completion lists sorted horizontally, that is, the second match is to the right of the first one, not under it as usual.

LIST_TYPES (-X)
    
```

--------------------------------

TITLE: Zsh History Configuration Options
DESCRIPTION: Details various Zsh options for configuring history behavior, including appending to a file, handling duplicates, enabling substitution, and timestamping.

SOURCE: https://zsh.sourceforge.io/Doc/Release/zsh_2

LANGUAGE: zsh
CODE:
```
# Example Zsh options related to history:
# setopt append_history  # Append history to file instead of overwriting
# setopt hist_ignore_dups # Ignore duplicate commands
# setopt hist_verify      # Show command before executing after history expansion
# setopt timestamping     # Add timestamps to history entries
```

--------------------------------

TITLE: Zsh Parameter Usage
DESCRIPTION: Documentation on how specific parameters are utilized within the Zsh shell, such as the AUTO_PUSHD option.

SOURCE: https://zsh.sourceforge.io/Doc/Release/Options-Index

LANGUAGE: APIDOC
CODE:
```
AUTO_PUSHD, use of:
  - Description: Controls the behavior of the AUTO_PUSHD option, which affects directory stacking.
  - Related Options: AUTO_PUSHD, AUTO_CD
```

--------------------------------

TITLE: Zmodload Parameter Management
DESCRIPTION: Manages autoloaded parameters. The -ap option works like -b and -c but for parameters. -up removes parameter definitions. The -L option lists all defined parameter names as zmodload commands.

SOURCE: https://zsh.sourceforge.io/Doc/Release/Shell-Builtin-Commands

LANGUAGE: zsh
CODE:
```
zmodload -ap [ -L ]
zmodload -ap [ -i ] name [ parameter ... ]
zmodload -up [ -i ] parameter ...
```

--------------------------------

TITLE: Zsh Menu Selection Parameters
DESCRIPTION: Configuration parameters for Zsh's menu selection feature. These control automatic activation, prompts, and scrolling behavior.

SOURCE: https://zsh.sourceforge.io/Doc/Release/Zsh-Modules

LANGUAGE: zsh
CODE:
```
MENUSELECT: Sets the minimum number of matches for automatic menu selection.
MENUPROMPT: Defines the prompt displayed when more matches than fit on screen.
MENUSCROLL: Controls how the match list is scrolled (line-by-line, half-screen, or custom).
```

--------------------------------

TITLE: Zsh Completion Option -e Parameter Expansion
DESCRIPTION: This flag informs the completion code that the added matches are parameter names for parameter expansion. Consequently, the `AUTO_PARAM_SLASH` and `AUTO_PARAM_KEYS` options will be applied to these matches.

SOURCE: https://zsh.sourceforge.io/Doc/Release/Completion-Widgets

LANGUAGE: zsh
CODE:
```
-e
```

--------------------------------

TITLE: SH_OPTION_LETTERS Option
DESCRIPTION: Details the SH_OPTION_LETTERS option, which controls how Zsh interprets single-letter options used with `set` and `setopt`. When this option is enabled, Zsh mimics the behavior of ksh in interpreting these options, which also influences the value of the special parameter `-`.

SOURCE: https://zsh.sourceforge.io/Doc/Release/Options

LANGUAGE: zsh
CODE:
```
`SH_OPTION_LETTERS` <K> <S> 
If this option is set the shell tries to interpret single letter options (which are used with `set` and `setopt`) like ksh does. This also affects the value of the `-` special parameter.
```

content.text: Now let me get some practical configuration examples from the "Mastering Zsh" guide:

input.topic: configuration zshrc startup customization options environment

content.text:
================
CODE SNIPPETS
================
TITLE: Set ZDOTDIR Environment Variable for Zsh Configuration
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to reconfigure the default location for Zsh's configuration files by setting the `ZDOTDIR` environment variable within the `$HOME/.zshenv` file. This allows users to centralize their Zsh dotfiles in a custom directory, improving organization and portability.

SOURCE: https://github.com/rothgar/mastering-zsh/blob/master/docs/config/general.md#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: bash
CODE:
```
# $HOME/.zshenv

export ZDOTDIR=$HOME/.dotfiles/zdotdir
```

--------------------------------

TITLE: Configure Zsh History Recording Options
DESCRIPTION: This snippet provides a set of `setopt` commands to enhance Zsh's history management. It configures features like immediate history saving, sharing history across sessions, and various duplicate handling rules to maintain a cleaner and more useful command history.

SOURCE: https://github.com/rothgar/mastering-zsh/blob/master/docs/config/history.md#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: zsh
CODE:
```
setopt EXTENDED_HISTORY          # Write the history file in the ':start:elapsed;command' format.
setopt INC_APPEND_HISTORY        # Write to the history file immediately, not when the shell exits.
setopt SHARE_HISTORY             # Share history between all sessions.
setopt HIST_EXPIRE_DUPS_FIRST    # Expire a duplicate event first when trimming history.
setopt HIST_IGNORE_DUPS          # Do not record an event that was just recorded again.
setopt HIST_IGNORE_ALL_DUPS      # Delete an old recorded event if a new event is a duplicate.
setopt HIST_FIND_NO_DUPS         # Do not display a previously found event.
setopt HIST_IGNORE_SPACE         # Do not record an event starting with a space.
setopt HIST_SAVE_NO_DUPS         # Do not write a duplicate event to the history file.
setopt HIST_VERIFY               # Do not execute immediately upon history expansion.
setopt APPEND_HISTORY            # append to history file
setopt HIST_NO_STORE             # Don't store history commands
```

--------------------------------

TITLE: Load Custom Zsh Prompt Theme
DESCRIPTION: Illustrates the process of adding a custom directory to Zsh's function path ($fpath) and then loading a custom prompt theme. This allows the `prompt` command to discover and activate user-defined prompt setups, assuming the theme's setup file follows the `prompt_*_setup` naming convention.

SOURCE: https://github.com/rothgar/mastering-zsh/blob/master/docs/config/prompt.md#_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: bash
CODE:
```
fpath=($ZDOTDIR/prompts $fpath)

autoload -Uz promptinit; promptinit
prompt MyAwesomePrompt     # Looks for $ZDOTDIR/promts/prompt_MyAwesomePrompt_setup
```

--------------------------------

TITLE: Configure Zsh Right Prompt (RPROMPT)
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to set the Zsh right prompt ($RPROMPT) to display dynamic information. Examples include showing the current time and Git repository status, illustrating how $RPROMPT can enhance terminal information display on the right side.

SOURCE: https://github.com/rothgar/mastering-zsh/blob/master/docs/config/prompt.md#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: bash
CODE:
```
# Show time on the right side of the screen
export RPROMPT='%t'

# show git repo info in your prompt
export RPROMPT='$vcs_info_msg_0_'
```

--------------------------------

TITLE: Add Directory to fpath and Autoload Zsh Function
DESCRIPTION: Illustrates the process of extending Zsh's function search path (`$fpath`) to include custom directories. It shows how to create a simple shared function file, and then use the `autoload` command to load and execute the function, demonstrating Zsh's powerful function portability features.

SOURCE: https://github.com/rothgar/mastering-zsh/blob/master/docs/config/general.md#_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: bash
CODE:
```
# Add our own functions folder to fpath
export fpath=($ZDOTDIR/functions $fpath)

# Create a file called blah in $ZDOTDIR/functions folder
$ echo 'echo blah blah' > ${fpath[1]}/blah

$ autoload -U blah

$ blah
blah blah
```

--------------------------------

TITLE: Source Zsh Plugin Files from zsh.d Directory
DESCRIPTION: Provides a robust method for sourcing Zsh plugin files from a designated `zsh.d` directory. It uses a `for` loop with a glob qualifier `(N)` to prevent errors if the directory is empty or missing, ensuring flexible plugin management and modular configuration.

SOURCE: https://github.com/rothgar/mastering-zsh/blob/master/docs/config/general.md#_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: bash
CODE:
```
for ZSH_FILE in "${ZDOTDIR:-$HOME}"/zsh.d/*.zsh(N); do
    source "${ZSH_FILE}"
done
```

--------------------------------

TITLE: Initialize Zsh Prompt System
DESCRIPTION: Loads and initializes the standard Zsh prompt system's `promptinit` widget. This command is essential for enabling the `prompt` command, which allows users to list, select, and manage Zsh prompt themes.

SOURCE: https://github.com/rothgar/mastering-zsh/blob/master/docs/config/prompt.md#_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: bash
CODE:
```
autoload -Uz promptinit; promptinit
```

--------------------------------

TITLE: Basic Setup for Zsh User-Defined Widgets
DESCRIPTION: Essential commands (`autoload -U`, `zle -N`, `bindkey`) required to define and make a custom Zsh widget available for use, typically placed in `.zshrc`.

SOURCE: https://github.com/rothgar/mastering-zsh/blob/master/docs/helpers/widgets.md#_snippet_3

LANGUAGE: bash
CODE:
```
autoload -U $WIDGET
zle -N $WIDGET
bindkey $KEY_SEQUENCE $WIDGET
```

--------------------------------

TITLE: List Zsh Widgets and Keybindings
DESCRIPTION: Commands to display all available Zsh widgets and current keyboard shortcuts, including those formatted for `.zshrc` configuration.

SOURCE: https://github.com/rothgar/mastering-zsh/blob/master/docs/helpers/widgets.md#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: bash
CODE:
```
zle -al
```

LANGUAGE: bash
CODE:
```
bindkey
```

LANGUAGE: bash
CODE:
```
bindkey -L
```

--------------------------------

TITLE: Configure Zsh Bash-style Word Selection
DESCRIPTION: This snippet configures Zsh to use a word selection style similar to Bash, which treats characters like `/` and `-` as word delimiters. This is useful for users accustomed to Bash's word navigation behavior, preventing commands like `delete-word` from consuming entire paths.

SOURCE: https://github.com/rothgar/mastering-zsh/blob/master/docs/usage/line_movement.md#_snippet_4

LANGUAGE: bash
CODE:
```
autoload -U select-word-style
select-word-style bash
```

--------------------------------

TITLE: Define Zsh Global Aliases for Command Line Anywhere
DESCRIPTION: Illustrates the use of Zsh's global aliases, enabled with the `-g` option. Global aliases can be matched and expanded anywhere on the command line, not just at the beginning, making them versatile for common text patterns.

SOURCE: https://github.com/rothgar/mastering-zsh/blob/master/docs/helpers/aliases.md#_snippet_4

LANGUAGE: bash
CODE:
```
alias -g G='| grep'
alias -g L='| less'
alias -g W='| wc -l'
alias -g C='| tr -d ''\n'' | xclip -selection clipboard'
```

--------------------------------

TITLE: Display Zsh WORDCHARS Environment Variable
DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to view the current value of the Zsh `WORDCHARS` environment variable. `WORDCHARS` defines which characters are considered part of a 'word' by the shell, influencing word-based navigation and editing commands.

SOURCE: https://github.com/rothgar/mastering-zsh/blob/master/docs/usage/line_movement.md#_snippet_3

LANGUAGE: bash
CODE:
```
echo $WORDCHARS
```

--------------------------------

TITLE: Adding Custom Functions to Zsh Hooks with add-zsh-hook
DESCRIPTION: This snippet illustrates how to extend existing Zsh hooks by adding custom functions using the `add-zsh-hook` utility. It defines a `do-ls` function and then adds it to the `chpwd` hook, which executes whenever the current working directory changes. The example shows the `ls` command being automatically run after changing directories.

SOURCE: https://github.com/rothgar/mastering-zsh/blob/master/docs/config/hooks.md#_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: zsh
CODE:
```
# create a do-ls function
# Make sure to use emulate -L zsh or
# your shell settings and a directory
# named 'rm' could be deadly
do-ls() {emulate -L zsh; ls;}

# add do-ls to chpwd hook
add-zsh-hook chpwd do-ls

cd ~/
Desktop     Music
Documents	Pictures
Downloads	Public
```

--------------------------------

TITLE: Generate Zsh Bindkey Commands for .zshrc
DESCRIPTION: Use this command to output the complete `bindkey` commands that can be directly added to your `.zshrc` file. This helps in persisting custom key bindings across shell sessions, ensuring your preferred shortcuts are loaded every time Zsh starts.

SOURCE: https://github.com/rothgar/mastering-zsh/blob/master/docs/helpers/bindkey.md#_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: zsh
CODE:
```
bindkey -L
```

--------------------------------

TITLE: Zsh Keybindings for Command History and Editing
DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to configure keybindings in Zsh's `viins` mode for enhanced command line editing. It re-sets shortcuts for `push-line-or-edit`, `yank`, `yank-pop`, and `backward-kill-line`, enabling users to cycle through a kill ring of previously yanked commands and manage their command history more effectively.

SOURCE: https://github.com/rothgar/mastering-zsh/blob/master/docs/usage/line_movement.md#_snippet_8

LANGUAGE: Bash
CODE:
```
# re-sets yank and kill shortcuts to bash/emacs mode
bindkey -M viins '^P' push-line-or-edit
bindkey -M viins '^Y' yank
# in order to use the below you must first yank without hitting enter
# subsequent alt-y combos will cycle through
# kill ring
bindkey -M viins '\ey' yank-pop
bindkey -M viins '^U' backward-kill-line
```

--------------------------------

TITLE: Enabling Automatic Directory Change with Zsh `AUTO_CD`
DESCRIPTION: Shows how to activate the `AUTO_CD` option in Zsh, allowing users to change directories simply by typing the directory name. This works provided the directory name is not an existing command, streamlining navigation for frequently accessed paths.

SOURCE: https://github.com/rothgar/mastering-zsh/blob/master/docs/usage/navigation.md#_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: bash
CODE:
```
$ ls
foo/ bar/ some.txt

$ setopt auto_cd

# cd into foo
$ foo

$ pwd
~/foo

# change directory to other parts of the filesystem with full paths
$ ls /var/log/
apache docker

$ /var/log/apache
```

--------------------------------

TITLE: Basic `cd` Commands in Zsh
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates fundamental `cd` commands for navigating to the home directory and the previous directory, applicable in any shell environment.

SOURCE: https://github.com/rothgar/mastering-zsh/blob/master/docs/usage/navigation.md#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: bash
CODE:
```
# change directory to your $HOME with just the cd command
cd

# change directory to the previous directory with
cd -
```

--------------------------------

TITLE: Define Zsh Aliases Using Other Aliases
DESCRIPTION: Shows that aliases can be used within the definitions of other aliases. This allows for modular and reusable alias configurations, building more complex aliases from simpler ones.

SOURCE: https://github.com/rothgar/mastering-zsh/blob/master/docs/helpers/aliases.md#_snippet_6

LANGUAGE: bash
CODE:
```
alias -g G='| grep'
alias -g W='| wc -l'
alias -g GfooW='G foo W'
```

--------------------------------

TITLE: Configure Basic Zsh Line Movement Keybindings
DESCRIPTION: This snippet sets up common keybindings for efficient line navigation and basic editing in Zsh. It binds `Ctrl+r` for reverse history search, `Ctrl+a` for beginning of line, `Ctrl+e` for end of line, and `Ctrl+?` (backspace) for character deletion, enhancing usability across keymap modes.

SOURCE: https://github.com/rothgar/mastering-zsh/blob/master/docs/usage/line_movement.md#_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: bash
CODE:
```
bindkey '^r' history-incremental-search-backward
bindkey '^a' beginning-of-line
bindkey '^e' end-of-line
# Also fix annoying vi backspace
bindkey '^?' backward-delete-char
```

--------------------------------

TITLE: Custom Zsh Function for Backward Path Deletion
DESCRIPTION: This Zsh function, `default-backward-delete-word`, customizes the behavior of backward word deletion. It temporarily sets the `WORDCHARS` variable to include path-related characters, allowing `zle backward-delete-word` to delete an entire directory path. The function is then bound to `^W` for easy access.

SOURCE: https://github.com/rothgar/mastering-zsh/blob/master/docs/usage/line_movement.md#_snippet_7

LANGUAGE: Zsh
CODE:
```
default-backward-delete-word () {
  local WORDCHARS="*?_[]~=/&;!#$%^(){}<>"
  zle backward-delete-word
}
zle -N default-backward-delete-word
bindkey '^W' default-backward-delete-word
```

--------------------------------

TITLE: Set Zsh RPROMPT with Last Exit Code via precmd Hook (Direct Assignment)
DESCRIPTION: This Zsh script demonstrates how to dynamically set the right prompt (`$RPROMPT`) based on the exit code of the previous command. It uses the `precmd` hook, which executes before each new prompt, and appends a custom function `check_last_exit_code` to the `precmd_functions` array. The function directly assigns the formatted exit code to `RPROMPT`.

SOURCE: https://github.com/rothgar/mastering-zsh/blob/master/docs/config/hooks.md#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: zsh
CODE:
```
# allows parameter expansion, arithmatic, and shell substitution in prompts
setopt prompt_subst

function check_last_exit_code() {
  local LAST_EXIT_CODE=$?
  if [[ $LAST_EXIT_CODE -ne 0 ]]; then
    local EXIT_CODE_PROMPT=' '
    EXIT_CODE_PROMPT+="%{$fg[red]%}-%{$reset_color%}"
    EXIT_CODE_PROMPT+="%{$fg_bold[red]%}$LAST_EXIT_CODE%{$reset_color%}"
    EXIT_CODE_PROMPT+="%{$fg[red]%}-%{$reset_color%}"
    RPROMPT="$EXIT_CODE_PROMPT"
  else
    RPROMPT=' '
  fi
}

typeset -a precmd_functions
# append the function to our array of precmd functions
precmd_functions+=(check_last_exit_code)
```

--------------------------------

TITLE: Load zmv Function in Zsh
DESCRIPTION: Illustrates how to load the `zmv` user-contributed function into a Zsh session or a `.zshrc` configuration file. The `autoload -U` command ensures the function is loaded and marked as unique.

SOURCE: https://github.com/rothgar/mastering-zsh/blob/master/docs/usage/file_management.md#_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: bash
CODE:
```
autoload -U zmv
```

--------------------------------

TITLE: Zsh `select-word-style` Command Reference
DESCRIPTION: This snippet provides the usage information for the Zsh `select-word-style` command. It details the various word styles available, such as bash, normal, shell, whitespace, and default, explaining how each defines word boundaries for Zsh operations. It also notes the `(q)uit` option.

SOURCE: https://github.com/rothgar/mastering-zsh/blob/master/docs/usage/line_movement.md#_snippet_6

LANGUAGE: Zsh
CODE:
```
select-word-style
Usage: select-word-style word-style
where word-style is one of the characters in parentheses:
(b)ash:       Word characters are alphanumerics only
(n)ormal:     Word characters are alphanumerics plus $WORDCHARS
(s)hell:      Words are command arguments using shell syntax
(w)hitespace: Words are whitespace-delimited
(d)efault:    Use default, no special handling (usually same as `n')
(q)uit:       Quit without setting a new style
```

--------------------------------

TITLE: Custom Function for Basic History Search (h)
DESCRIPTION: A Zsh function named `h` that provides a convenient way to search through your command history. If called without arguments, it lists the entire history. If arguments are provided, it filters the history using `egrep` to find matching commands.

SOURCE: https://github.com/rothgar/mastering-zsh/blob/master/docs/config/history.md#_snippet_11

LANGUAGE: bash
CODE:
```
function h() {
    # check if we passed any parameters
    if [ -z "$*" ]; then
        # if no parameters were passed print entire history
        history 1
    else
        # if words were passed use it as a search
        history 1 | egrep --color=auto "$@"
    fi
}

# search entire history for "foo" with
h foo
```

--------------------------------

TITLE: Delete a Zsh Key Binding
DESCRIPTION: This command allows you to remove a specific key binding from your Zsh configuration. Replace `$KEYS` with the actual key sequence you wish to unbind. Exercise caution to avoid deleting essential characters or commands that are crucial for shell operation.

SOURCE: https://github.com/rothgar/mastering-zsh/blob/master/docs/helpers/bindkey.md#_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: zsh
CODE:
```
bindkey -d $KEYS
```

--------------------------------

TITLE: Bind Key for Smart Insert Last Word in Zsh
DESCRIPTION: This snippet configures a Zsh Line Editor (ZLE) widget to insert the last word from the previous command. It uses `autoload` to load the `smart-insert-last-word` function, registers it as a ZLE widget, and binds it to `Alt+.` (escape sequence `\e.`) for quick access.

SOURCE: https://github.com/rothgar/mastering-zsh/blob/master/docs/config/history.md#_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: zsh
CODE:
```
# press Alt+. to insert the last word from the previous command
autoload -U smart-insert-last-word
zle -N smart-insert-last-word
bindkey "\e." smart-insert-last-word
```

--------------------------------

TITLE: Interactive History Search with ZLE (ctrl+r)
DESCRIPTION: This snippet configures Zsh's Line Editor (ZLE) to provide an advanced interactive history search. It allows users to search history incrementally and combine multiple commands from history onto a single line by pressing `Alt+;` after selecting a command.

SOURCE: https://github.com/rothgar/mastering-zsh/blob/master/docs/config/history.md#_snippet_12

LANGUAGE: bash
CODE:
```
# add the ability to print >> << for the portion of the cli we'll be using
autoload -Uz narrow-to-region

# define our function
function _history-incremental-preserving-pattern-search-backward
{
  local state
  MARK=CURSOR  
  narrow-to-region -p "$LBUFFER${BUFFER:+>>}" -P "${BUFFER:+<<}$RBUFFER" -S state
  zle end-of-history
  zle history-incremental-pattern-search-backward
  narrow-to-region -R state
}

# load the function into zle
zle -N _history-incremental-preserving-pattern-search-backward

# bind it to ctrl+r
bindkey "^R" _history-incremental-preserving-pattern-search-backward
bindkey -M isearch "^R" history-incremental-pattern-search-backward
bindkey "^S" history-incremental-pattern-search-forward
```

TITLE: Prepend Sudo to Current Command Widget
DESCRIPTION: A Zsh user-defined widget that prepends `sudo ` to the current command buffer and repositions the cursor. This example binds it to `s` in `vicmd` mode.

```
function prepend-sudo {

  fi
```

TITLE: Configure Zsh History Recording Options
DESCRIPTION: This snippet provides a set of `setopt` commands to enhance Zsh's history management. It configures features like immediate history saving, sharing history across sessions, and various duplicate handling rules to maintain a cleaner and more useful command history.

SOURCE: https://github.com/rothgar/mastering-zsh/blob/master/docs/config/history.md#_snippet_0

```
setopt EXTENDED_HISTORY          # Write the history file in the ':start:elapsed;command' format.
setopt INC_APPEND_HISTORY        # Write to the history file immediately, not when the shell exits.
setopt SHARE_HISTORY             # Share history between all sessions.
setopt HIST_EXPIRE_DUPS_FIRST    # Expire a duplicate event first when trimming history.
setopt HIST_IGNORE_DUPS          # Do not record an event that was just recorded again.
setopt HIST_IGNORE_ALL_DUPS      # Delete an old recorded event if a new event is a duplicate.
setopt HIST_FIND_NO_DUPS         # Do not display a previously found event.
setopt HIST_IGNORE_SPACE         # Do not record an event starting with a space.
setopt HIST_SAVE_NO_DUPS         # Do not write a duplicate event to the history file.
setopt HIST_VERIFY               # Do not execute immediately upon history expansion.

```

TITLE: Set Zsh RPROMPT with Last Exit Code via precmd Hook (Direct Assignment)
DESCRIPTION: This Zsh script demonstrates how to dynamically set the right prompt (`$RPROMPT`) based on the exit code of the previous command. It uses the `precmd` hook, which executes before each new prompt, and appends a custom function `check_last_exit_code` to the `precmd_functions` array. The function directly assigns the formatted exit code to `RPROMPT`.

SOURCE: https://github.com/rothgar/mastering-zsh/blob/master/docs/config/hooks.md#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: zsh
CODE:
```
# allows parameter expansion, arithmatic, and shell substitution in prompts
setopt prompt_subst

function check_last_exit_code() {
  local LAST_EXIT_CODE=$?
  if [[ $LAST_EXIT_CODE -ne 0 ]]; then
    local EXIT_CODE_PROMPT=' '
    EXIT_CODE_PROMPT+="%{$fg[red]%}-%{$reset_color%}"
    EXIT_CODE_PROMPT+="%{$fg_bold[red]%}$LAST_EXIT_CODE%{$reset_color%}"
    EXIT_CODE_PROMPT+="%{$fg[red]%}-%{$reset_color%}"
    RPROMPT="$EXIT_CODE_PROMPT"
  else
    RPROMPT=' '
  fi
}

typeset -a precmd_functions
# append the function to our array of precmd functions
precmd_functions+=(check_last_exit_code)
```

```
(s)hell:      Words are command arguments using shell syntax
```

SOURCE: https://github.com/rothgar/mastering-zsh/blob/master/docs/config/history.md#_snippet_11

LANGUAGE: bash
CODE:
```
function h() {
    # check if we passed any parameters
    if [ -z "$*" ]; then
        # if no parameters were passed print entire history
        history 1
    else
        # if words were passed use it as a search
        history 1 | egrep --color=auto "$@"
    fi
}

```

Based on the Context7 documentation, here's what I found about Zsh and its configuration:

## Zsh Configuration Overview

**Startup Files and Order:**
Zsh reads configuration files in a specific order depending on the shell type:

1. **Always read:** `/etc/zshenv` ‚Üí `$ZDOTDIR/.zshenv` 
2. **Login shells:** `/etc/zprofile` ‚Üí `$ZDOTDIR/.zprofile`
3. **Interactive shells:** `/etc/zshrc` ‚Üí `$ZDOTDIR/.zshrc`
4. **Login shells (after zshrc):** `/etc/zlogin` ‚Üí `$ZDOTDIR/.zlogin`
5. **Logout:** `$ZDOTDIR/.zlogout` ‚Üí `/etc/zlogout`

**Key Configuration Variables:**
- `ZDOTDIR`: Directory for user config files (default: `$HOME`)
- `HISTSIZE`: Max events in memory
- `SAVEHIST`: Max events saved to history file
- `WORDCHARS`: Characters considered part of a "word"
- `fpath`: Function search path for autoloading

**Important Options:**
- `RCS`: Controls whether startup files are sourced
- `GLOBAL_RCS`: Controls system-wide startup files
- `EXTENDED_HISTORY`: Enhanced history with timestamps
- `SHARE_HISTORY`: Share history between sessions
- `AUTO_CD`: Change directory by typing its name

**Configuration Best Practices:**

1. **Modular configuration:** Source files from a `zsh.d` directory:
```zsh
for ZSH_FILE in "${ZDOTDIR:-$HOME}"/zsh.d/*.zsh(N); do
    source "${ZSH_FILE}"
done
```

2. **History optimization:**
```zsh
setopt EXTENDED_HISTORY
setopt INC_APPEND_HISTORY
setopt SHARE_HISTORY
setopt HIST_EXPIRE_DUPS_FIRST
setopt HIST_IGNORE_DUPS
```

3. **Custom functions:** Add to fpath and autoload:
```zsh
fpath=($ZDOTDIR/functions $fpath)
autoload -U function_name
```

4. **Prompt customization:** Use `promptinit` for themes:
```zsh
autoload -Uz promptinit; promptinit
```

**Advanced Features:**
- **Hooks:** Functions triggered by events (chpwd, precmd, preexec)
- **Widgets:** Custom ZLE (line editor) functions
- **Global aliases:** Aliases that work anywhere in a command
- **Completion system:** Powerful tab completion with `compinit`

The documentation shows Zsh is highly configurable with extensive options for history management, prompt customization, completion behavior, and startup file organization.

#!/usr/bin/env bash
#
# Launch zsh with our new configuration
# This allows testing without affecting the current setup
#

# Get the directory where this script lives
SCRIPT_DIR="$(cd "$(dirname "${BASH_SOURCE[0]}")" && pwd)"

# Set ZDOTDIR to our new config location
export ZDOTDIR="${SCRIPT_DIR}/config"

# Optional: Clear any oh-my-zsh environment variables
unset ZSH
unset ZSH_THEME
unset ZSH_CUSTOM

# Launch zsh with our new config
echo "Starting zsh with config from: $ZDOTDIR"
exec zsh "$@"

# .zshenv - First file sourced by zsh (always)
# Keep this minimal - only essential environment variables

# Ensure ZDOTDIR is set (in case we source this directly)
: ${ZDOTDIR:=$HOME/.config/zsh}

# XDG Base Directory Specification
export XDG_CONFIG_HOME="${XDG_CONFIG_HOME:-$HOME/.config}"
export XDG_CACHE_HOME="${XDG_CACHE_HOME:-$HOME/.cache}"
export XDG_DATA_HOME="${XDG_DATA_HOME:-$HOME/.local/share}"
export XDG_STATE_HOME="${XDG_STATE_HOME:-$HOME/.local/state}"

# Ensure essential directories exist
[[ ! -d "$XDG_CACHE_HOME/zsh" ]] && mkdir -p "$XDG_CACHE_HOME/zsh"
[[ ! -d "$XDG_DATA_HOME/zsh" ]] && mkdir -p "$XDG_DATA_HOME/zsh"
[[ ! -d "$XDG_STATE_HOME/zsh" ]] && mkdir -p "$XDG_STATE_HOME/zsh"

# Essential environment
export EDITOR="${EDITOR:-vim}"
export VISUAL="${VISUAL:-$EDITOR}"
export PAGER="${PAGER:-less}"

# Locale (important for proper character handling)
export LANG="${LANG:-en_US.UTF-8}"
export LC_ALL="${LC_ALL:-en_US.UTF-8}"

input.content:
# .zshrc - Interactive shell configuration
# Clean, modular zsh configuration without framework dependencies

# ============================================================================
# PERFORMANCE PROFILING (uncomment to debug slow startup)
# ============================================================================
# zmodload zsh/zprof

# ============================================================================
# CORE OPTIONS
# ============================================================================

# Directory navigation
setopt AUTO_CD              # cd by just typing directory name
setopt AUTO_PUSHD           # cd pushes directories onto stack
setopt PUSHD_IGNORE_DUPS    # Don't push duplicates
setopt PUSHD_SILENT         # Don't print directory stack after pushd/popd
setopt PUSHD_TO_HOME        # pushd with no args goes to home
setopt CDABLE_VARS          # cd into variable values

# Globbing and matching
setopt EXTENDED_GLOB        # Extended globbing patterns
setopt GLOB_DOTS            # Glob matches dotfiles
setopt NO_CASE_GLOB         # Case insensitive globbing
setopt NUMERIC_GLOB_SORT    # Sort numeric filenames numerically

# Job control
setopt NO_HUP               # Don't send HUP to background jobs on exit
setopt NO_BG_NICE           # Don't nice background jobs
setopt CHECK_JOBS           # Warn about background jobs on exit
setopt LONG_LIST_JOBS       # Display PID when suspending processes

# Input/Output
setopt CORRECT              # Command correction
setopt NO_FLOW_CONTROL      # Disable Ctrl-S/Ctrl-Q flow control
setopt INTERACTIVE_COMMENTS # Allow comments in interactive mode
setopt RC_QUOTES            # Allow 'Henry''s Garage' instead of 'Henry'\''s Garage'

# ============================================================================
# COMPLETION SYSTEM
# ============================================================================

# Add custom completions to fpath
fpath=("$ZDOTDIR/completions" $fpath)

# Load and initialize completion system
autoload -Uz compinit

# Use cached completions (regenerate once per day)
# This significantly speeds up shell startup
typeset -i updated_at=$(date +'%j' -r "$XDG_CACHE_HOME/zsh/zcompdump" 2>/dev/null || echo 0)
if [[ $(date +'%j') -ne $updated_at ]]; then
  compinit -d "$XDG_CACHE_HOME/zsh/zcompdump"
else
  compinit -C -d "$XDG_CACHE_HOME/zsh/zcompdump"
fi

# Basic completion settings
zstyle ':completion:*' menu select                        # Interactive menu selection
zstyle ':completion:*' matcher-list 'm:{a-z}={A-Z}'      # Case insensitive matching
zstyle ':completion:*' list-colors ''                     # Colorize completions
zstyle ':completion:*' group-name ''                      # Group completions by type
zstyle ':completion:*:descriptions' format '%B%d%b'       # Bold descriptions

# Speed up completions
zstyle ':completion:*' accept-exact '*(N)'
zstyle ':completion:*' use-cache on
zstyle ':completion:*' cache-path "$XDG_CACHE_HOME/zsh/zcompcache"

# ============================================================================
# KEY BINDINGS
# ============================================================================

# Use emacs key bindings (change to 'bindkey -v' for vi mode)
bindkey -e

# Common keybindings that should work everywhere
bindkey '^[[1;5C' forward-word        # Ctrl+Right
bindkey '^[[1;5D' backward-word       # Ctrl+Left
bindkey '^[[H' beginning-of-line      # Home
bindkey '^[[F' end-of-line           # End
bindkey '^[[3~' delete-char          # Delete
bindkey '^R' history-incremental-search-backward

# ============================================================================
# FUNCTIONS PATH
# ============================================================================

# Add custom functions directory to fpath
fpath=("$ZDOTDIR/functions" $fpath)

# ============================================================================
# PROMPT
# ============================================================================

# Enable prompt substitution
setopt PROMPT_SUBST

# Simple, clean prompt (customize as needed)
# Showing: username@host:directory %/#
PROMPT='%F{blue}%n@%m%f:%F{cyan}%~%f %# '

# Right prompt showing exit code when non-zero
RPROMPT='%(?..[%F{red}%?%f])'

# ============================================================================
# ALIASES
# ============================================================================

# Directory navigation
alias ..='cd ..'
alias ...='cd ../..'
alias ....='cd ../../..'
alias ~='cd ~'

# ls aliases (detect if GNU ls is available)
if command -v gls &>/dev/null; then
    alias ls='gls --color=auto'
else
    alias ls='ls --color=auto' 2>/dev/null || alias ls='ls -G'
fi
alias l='ls -lFh'
alias la='ls -lAFh'
alias ll='ls -l'

# Safety nets
alias rm='rm -i'
alias cp='cp -i'
alias mv='mv -i'

# Utilities
alias grep='grep --color=auto'
alias df='df -h'
alias du='du -h'
alias free='free -m'

# ============================================================================
# LOAD MODULAR CONFIGURATIONS
# ============================================================================

# Source all .zsh files from conf.d directory
# This allows splitting configuration into logical modules
for config_file in "$ZDOTDIR"/conf.d/*.zsh(N); do
    source "$config_file"
done

# ============================================================================
# PROFILING (uncomment to debug slow startup)
# ============================================================================
# zprof

input.content:
# history.zsh - History configuration module

# ============================================================================
# HISTORY SETTINGS
# ============================================================================

# History file location (using XDG base directory)
export HISTFILE="$XDG_STATE_HOME/zsh/history"

# Ensure history directory exists
[[ ! -d "$XDG_STATE_HOME/zsh" ]] && mkdir -p "$XDG_STATE_HOME/zsh"

# History size
export HISTSIZE=50000         # Max events in internal history
export SAVEHIST=50000         # Max events in history file

# History options for better experience
setopt EXTENDED_HISTORY       # Write timestamps to history
setopt INC_APPEND_HISTORY     # Write to history immediately, not on exit
setopt SHARE_HISTORY          # Share history between sessions
setopt HIST_EXPIRE_DUPS_FIRST # Expire duplicates first when trimming
setopt HIST_IGNORE_DUPS       # Don't record immediate duplicates
setopt HIST_IGNORE_ALL_DUPS   # Delete old recorded entry if new is duplicate
setopt HIST_FIND_NO_DUPS      # Don't display duplicates when searching
setopt HIST_IGNORE_SPACE      # Don't record commands starting with space
setopt HIST_SAVE_NO_DUPS      # Don't write duplicates to history file
setopt HIST_REDUCE_BLANKS     # Remove superfluous blanks before recording
setopt HIST_VERIFY            # Show command before executing from history

# ============================================================================
# HISTORY SEARCH KEYBINDINGS
# ============================================================================

# Up/Down arrows search history based on current input
autoload -U up-line-or-beginning-search
autoload -U down-line-or-beginning-search
zle -N up-line-or-beginning-search
zle -N down-line-or-beginning-search
bindkey "^[[A" up-line-or-beginning-search    # Up arrow
bindkey "^[[B" down-line-or-beginning-search  # Down arrow

# Ctrl+R for reverse history search (already in main .zshrc)
# Additional history search bindings
bindkey '^S' history-incremental-search-forward

# ============================================================================
# HISTORY UTILITIES
# ============================================================================

# Function to search history with highlighting
h() {
    if [[ -z "$*" ]]; then
        # No arguments: show all history
        history 1
    else
        # With arguments: search history
        history 1 | grep -E --color=auto "$@"
    fi
}

# Function to show most used commands
hist-stats() {
    fc -l 1 \
        | awk '{CMD[$2]++;count++;}END { for (a in CMD)print CMD[a] " " CMD[a]/count*100 "% " a;}' \
        | grep -v "./" \
        | column -c3 -s " " -t \
        | sort -nr \
        | nl \
        | head -n ${1:-10}
}

# Clear history (with confirmation)
hist-clear() {
    echo -n "Clear all history? [y/N] "
    read -r response
    case "$response" in
        [yY][eE][sS]|[yY])
            echo "" > "$HISTFILE"
            fc -p "$HISTFILE"
            echo "History cleared."
            ;;
        *)
            echo "History not cleared."
            ;;
    esac
}
